snippet.textDisplay:
Great video! Nothing will change the recommendations you bring up:
1. Wash 🖐 hands 🖐 (20+ seconds! and twice if you want) after coming home, and after touching something from outside your house
2. Don’t touch face 🧑👦
3. Don’t shake hands 🚫🤝
4. Disinfect your cell phone often 🦠📱
5. If you feel fever cough, fatigue, get that checked out by Dr. 👩‍⚕️👨‍⚕️, as you normally would!
#AlertNotAnxious
snippet.textOriginal:
Great video! Nothing will change the recommendations you bring up:
1. Wash 🖐 hands 🖐 (20+ seconds! and twice if you want) after coming home, and after touching something from outside your house
2. Don’t touch face 🧑👦
3. Don’t shake hands 🚫🤝
4. Disinfect your cell phone often 🦠📱
5. If you feel fever cough, fatigue, get that checked out by Dr. 👩‍⚕️👨‍⚕️, as you normally would!
 #AlertNotAnxious

snippet.authorDisplayName: Robert Walker - fact checker and science blogger
snippet.textDisplay:
I recommend you watch the WHO press conferences. They explain why they don't call it a pandemic. The reason is that it can be contained and stopped from spreading globally. It is a pandemic when you decide there is nothing you can do to stop potentially everyone in the world getting it - and then you switch to protecting the vulnerable and quarantining infected people is no longer useful.

This is not at that stage. Indeed China is close to containing it, 9 countries have had no cases for 2 weeks, many have only imported cases, Singapore has almost contained their outbreak and Italy, South Korea and Iran can all contain thier epidemics using the same methods China used.

In this situation it is not a pandemic. It is multiple controllable epidemics in different countries.

From the WHO press conference last Friday:

"A pandemic is is a unique situation in which we believe that all citizens on the planet will likely be exposed to a virus within a defined period of time."

"If this were influenza we would probably have called this a pandemic by now—but what we've seen with this virus is that with containment measures and a robust Public Health response, the course of this epidemic, or these multiple epidemics, can be significantly altered"

"It is unhelpful to declare a pandemic when you're still trying to contain a disease."

See question and answer here
https://youtu.be/85ZX3v6z1uQ?t=1402

More background in my article here:
https://www.science20.com/robert_walker/china_close_to_containing_covid19_rest_of_world_can_stop_it_too_says_who_good_news_not_shared_on_mainstream_tv
(print preview - fills page without top or side nav)
https://www.science20.com/print/245849

snippet.textDisplay:
Here’s my thing... I live in Florida, which as a state “officials” have thus far been unwilling to release data pertaining to patients infected or possibly infected with COVID-19 due to HIPPA. BS, right? The Governor pushed something through the courts mandating the release of that information as it pertains to just the virus. Finally, some information is coming out. The other issue is that Florida JUST got test kits in Tampa (where I live), Jacksonville and Miami. Basically, major ports of entry for cruise lines. Here’s the deal with that- “Florida had hoped to begin testing people for COVID-19 by now at state laboratories in Miami, Jacksonville and Tampa. But the CDC said the test kits sent to states and intended to provide quick results proved faulty, and a manufacturer needs to remake them.
By Cindy Krischer Goodman, Sun Sentinel | February 24, 2020”
2 cases of the virus were “preemptively positive” in Hillsborough county (my county) as of last night.
My question for Dr. Mike: if there is a lack of transparency from medical professionals to the government, and lack of adequate testing equipment in Florida, a major tourist state for snowbirds this time of year, what can be done better? What are the odds that everyone walking around thinking “oh it’s just allergies.” is actually symptomatic and doesn’t realize it. #awarenotanxious #dontleavefloridainthedark #okiAMworried. Edit to add: newest update while I wrote this 2 confirmed cases in Florida, 184 being monitored.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: coronavirus can be treated like dengue virus which is much more dangerous than corona ... Dengue fever annually infects up to 100 million people and killed more than 40,000 in 2017 ...  in 2010 there were 684 million cases of norovirus, of which more than 200,000 people died. Even the seasonal flu, which can often be vaccinated against in many parts of the world, kills 300,000 to 650,000 people every year.

snippet.textDisplay:
RE: transmission to pets


Honestly ... I wouldn't rule it out. Cats can get FIP from the "normal" strain of coronavirus so cats with weaker immune systems might just contract this latest mutation of the coronavirus. If I tested positive for it, I certainly would avoid getting my snot and stuff on my cats.


Keep yourself and your pets clean. That is always the best way to prevent disease. I make it a habit to wash my hands when I get back home from being out and after cleaning up.


Most of us will be fine ... the elderly and immuno-deficient are the most at risk.
snippet.textOriginal:
RE: transmission to pets


Honestly ... I wouldn't rule it out. Cats can get FIP from the "normal" strain of coronavirus so cats with weaker immune systems might just contract this latest mutation of the coronavirus. If I tested positive for it, I certainly would avoid getting my snot and stuff on my cats.


Keep yourself and your pets clean. That is always the best way to prevent disease. I make it a habit to wash my hands when I get back home from being out and after cleaning up.


Most of us will be fine ... the elderly and immuno-deficient are the most at risk.

Hi dr.mike I have a question. Recently a hospital prematurely let out a patient who had the corona virus and she visited the mall and came in contact with 16 people. They have all been deemed medium risk. My fear is the mall is right across from my cosmetology school where I come in close contact with people everyday who frequently go to the mall before or after a service; students also go there for lunch cause it’s 2 minutes away. I also work right across in retail and come in contact with people again as well as taking the bus everyday. Besides washing hands and not touching my face are there any EXTRA precautions I can’t take because I can’t just not go to school or work ? I’m terrified
Sincerely, alert and anxious
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
Here's an 💡 Idea
If you feel semi-symptomatic or mildly symptomatic. Itch-ish throat and nose. Assume you are sick and wear a mask. Contain your germs and disinfect after yourself...
Rather than the inverse assuming you have allergies while you run around infecting others with your "allergies" only to end up in bed days later with a nasty virus... Which you just spread all over the place. Most masks work way better to contain germs than they protect against germs... Unless its just there reminding you not to touch your face. Lets change our thinking about this allergy/virus game as a culture. I understand you can't stop your life for mild symptoms, but you can contain the risk to others.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: @Doctor Mike.  Myeloma can be caused by exposure to radiation.  So can other blood diseases.  Even extended radiation treatments by a radiologist, such as for throat cancer or in my wife’s case a Desmoid Tumor, can lead to blood cancers or diseases.  So why would they use this, instead of NanoKnife or direct Hyperthermia?  I asked multiple times for that treatment for my wife and was denied.  1 year later after radiation, that did nothing, for a Desmoid Tumor, we are back seeing a hematologist for Leukaemia now...?  Any thoughts?

snippet.textDisplay: Better wear a mask if possible, I understand in the US or other western countries, wearing a mask may indicate that you are sick, but it is also a protection to you and people around you because you never know if the people around you are sick or not, if they are, and you get the virus, and with a 14-day incubation period, it's highly likely that you will pass it to others when you do not know causing a ripple effect, frankly, COVID-19 is the most contagious virus as far as I know, I don't think the phrase "mildly contagious" can properly describe its nature, this thing may pass you in a matter of a few seconds if you don't wear a mask, say in an elevator or standing next to a patient without protection, many people in the state may have not realized how serious this virus is, and those cult members in South Korea are the best proof. So wear a mask, wash your hands properly and routinely, try to avoid the crowds or gatherings, do not take any chance, there's no need to prove how tough you are when it come to a virus, as a Chinese, these are the advices I can give to you, hope this may help.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm so sorry that this is so redundant, I'm just having a hard time wrapping my mind around the mask protocol. We are told that the virus is transmittable through respiratory contact (droplets from someone's cough, sneeze, heavy breath, etc), therefore, wouldn't a mask that is graded to block PM2.5 (particles larger than 2.5 microns) be a barrier against the respiratory transmission? Then they say that the reason medical professionals wear them is because they are in close contact with patients, if anyone has ever taken public transit (ESPECIALLY in NYC) you understand how close you can end up to other people. Therefore, wouldn't it reduce risk of contracting the virus if you were wearing a mask that protects against the people who you are in close contact with, as the medical professionals do? I understand that people don't use the masks properly i.e: touching them on the inside/outside, pulling them down, not limiting themselves to only touching the ear straps, not disposing of properly, getting surgical masks that do nothing, having gaps where particles can enter etc. But for people who understand proper use of a mask that is N95/N99/N100 (filters out 95% ,99%, or 100% of particles greater than 2.5 microns) how is this not proper protocol to help protect against contracting the virus? I'm genuinely just confused, I'm not trying to make an argument for misinformation or that I somehow know more than medical professionals! I just feel that this information is contradicting and illogical based on my understanding of how masks work and how the virus is transmitted. I am a mere lay person who lives in NYC and has to take the subway everyday and in my lay person brain it seems logical to wear a mask if I can wear and utilize it properly and follow strict hand washing and surface sanitizing protocols. IDK.
snippet.textOriginal: I'm so sorry that this is so redundant, I'm just having a hard time wrapping my mind around the mask protocol. We are told that the virus is transmittable through respiratory contact (droplets from someone's cough, sneeze, heavy breath, etc), therefore, wouldn't a mask that is graded to block PM2.5 (particles larger than 2.5 microns) be a barrier against the respiratory transmission? Then they say that the reason medical professionals wear them is because they are in close contact with patients, if anyone has ever taken public transit (ESPECIALLY in NYC) you understand how close you can end up to other people. Therefore, wouldn't it reduce risk of contracting the virus if you were wearing a mask that protects against the people who you are in close contact with, as the medical professionals do? I understand that people don't use the masks properly i.e: touching them on the inside/outside, pulling them down, not limiting themselves to only touching the ear straps, not disposing of properly, getting surgical masks that do nothing, having gaps where particles can enter etc. But for people who understand proper use of a mask that is N95/N99/N100 (filters out 95% ,99%, or 100% of particles greater than 2.5 microns) how is this not proper protocol to help protect against contracting the virus? I'm genuinely just confused, I'm not trying to make an argument for misinformation or that I somehow know more than medical professionals! I just feel that this information is contradicting and illogical based on my understanding of how masks work and how the virus is transmitted. I am a mere lay person who lives in NYC and has to take the subway everyday and in my lay person brain it seems logical to wear a mask if I can wear and utilize it properly and follow strict hand washing and surface sanitizing protocols. IDK.

snippet.textDisplay:
"Hello, I'm Laila Ahmadi from China, Faculty of Medical Sciences, Zanjan University
Corona virus arrives in any country, sooner or later there is no doubt that many countries have no diagnostic sets or equipment, so
Please use as much as possible of natural vitamin C to strengthen your immune system.
Don't worry, C gets rid of it a lot, and it's fine.
Also make sure to use more yellow wood
In addition,
Tell yourself and your children that they are all supposed to be HIV-positive and don't touch anyone or regret it.
The virus currently contains no vaccine and no specific treatment
Unfortunately, due to the genetic mutation that made it very dangerous
This disease appears to be caused by gene fusion in a snake and bat, and it has acquired the ability to infect mammals, including humans.

It is important to keep the message on your greatest knowledge: Professor Chen Horin, CEO of the Beijing Military Hospital, said: "Slices of lemon in a cup of lukewarm water can save your life." *
Even if you work, you should take a look at this message and pass it on to others! Hot lemon can kill cancer cells! The lemon cut into three parts and put in a cup, then pour hot water and turn it into (alkaline water), drinking it every day will certainly benefit everyone. Hot lemons can release the anti-cancer drug again. Hot lemon juice appeared on cancerous tumors and cured all cancers.
Treatment with this extract only destroys malignant cells and does not affect healthy cells.
Second: the acids and carboxylic acid contained in lemon juice can regulate high blood pressure, protect narrow arteries, regulate blood circulation and reduce blood clotting.
After reading, talk to someone else and transfer it to the person you love and take care of your personal health.
Council:
Professor Chen Horin notes that anyone who receives this message is at least guaranteed to save someone's life...
I have done my job and I hope you can help me develop it as well.
They published it in academic groups"
Got this message forwarded in the college group.
What's your opinion?

snippet.textDisplay:
The issue in America isn't gonna be the fatality rate. It's gonna be the rate of people needing hospitalization, which is at least 10%. And the median hospital stay is 10 days. 10 days in hospital is gonna be extremely expensive for Americans without insurance, and cause a massive strain on the healthcare system. Most hospitals are already operating at capacity and would struggle with a sudden influx of patients.

Basically, if you're in America and you get it, it probably won't kill you. But it might drain your bank account if you don't have insurance.
